did.abstract: The Carla Stellweg papers document Stellweg's curatorial work, writing, and other professional activities. Materials include exhibition catalogs, correspondence, publications, photographic materials, and administrative records.
did.physloc: Special Collections materials are stored offsite and must be paged 36 hours in advance. For more information on paging collections, see the department's website: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/spc.html.
did.langmaterial: The material is in primarily in English and Spanish. Other languages include French, Finnish, Portuguese, Norwegian, Italian, German, Japanese, Swedish, Dutch and Arabic.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in ten series:

Series 1. Artists Series 2. Gallery Shows, Curatorial Work and Other Professional Activities Series 3. Frida Kahlo Exhibits Series 4. Articles, Reviews, and Other Writing Series 5. Publications Series 6. Personal and Biographical Information Series 7. Photographic Materials Series 8. Audiovisual Materials Series 9. Financial Records (Restricted) Series 10. Accession 2015-145. Additional Materials

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Carla Stellweg papers, M1752. Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: While Special Collections is the owner of the physical and digital items, permission to examine collection materials is not an authorization to publish. These materials are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study. Any transmission or reproduction beyond that allowed by fair use requires permission from the owners of rights, heir(s) or assigns.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection was purchased by Stanford University, Special Collections in 2010 and 2015. Accessions 2010-095 and 2015-145.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Carla Stellweg papers document Stellweg's curatorial work, writing, and other professional activities. Materials include exhibition catalogs, correspondence, publications, photographic materials, audiovisual materials and administrative records.
Accession 2015-145 includes photographs, slides, papers, journals, cassettes, and one hard drive.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p:
Carla Stellweg is a curator, art historian, and writer who specializes in the promotion of Latin American art and artists. Born in Bandung, Indonesia, she moved to Mexico with her family in the late 1950s, where she lived and worked for twenty-five years. Stellweg received a Bachelor of Arts from Grotius College and was a Master of Fine Arts Candidate in art history at the University of the Americas, Mexico.
Stellweg held a variety of curatorial and management positions throughout her career. She was the founder and editor of Artes Visuales, which was the first Spanish and English contemporary visual arts magazine published in Latin America. In 1979, Stellweg became the deputy director of the newly built Rufino Tamayo Museum. From 1983-1985, Stellweg was the director of the Stellweg-Seguy Gallery, managing exhibitions and sales. She became the chief curator of the Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art (MOCHA) in 1986, where she worked on exhibits such as Rooted Visions: Mexican Art Today. In 1989, she became the owner and director of her own gallery in New York City. The Carla Stellweg Gallery's mission was to promote emerging and mid-career artists, as well as to provide a gallery space for diverse exhibitions. Stellweg also worked as the executive director of Blue Star Art Space and as the director of program funding for the Jewish Museum, where she was in charge of an annual campaign to raise more than 3 million dollars. In 2005, Stellweg became an art history professor at the School of Visual Arts. In addition to these positions, Stellweg worked as an independent consultant on various projects, including Hispanic Art in the United States: Thirty Contemporary Painters and Sculptors and The Latin American Spirit: Art and Artists in the US, 1920-1970. Stellweg was a co-author of The Camera Seduced: Portraits of Frida Kahlo, a book which arose out of her work on an exhibition of the same name. She received a Rockefeller Fellowship in the Humanities, with the research topic "Exhibiting Practices of Mexican and Chicano Art: Its Funding and Collecting."

accessrestrict.head: Access to Collection
accessrestrict.p: Open for research except for Series 9 (restricted financial records). Audio-visual materials are not available in original format, and must be reformatted to a digital use copy.

Series 2. Gallery Shows, Curatorial Work and Other Professional Activities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series documents Stellweg's professional activities as a curator and director of various art galleries and museums, including her work at the Carla Stellweg Gallery, the Stellweg-Seguy Gallery, the Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art (MOCHA), the Rufino Tamayo Museum, Blue Star Art Space, and White Box. The series also documents Stellweg's professional consulting work and fundraising efforts. Materials include correspondence, documentation on artists and exhibitions, catalogs, exhibition invitations, appointment books, and administrative records. Information on Stellweg's involvement in exhibitions and projects such as Rooted Vision: Mexican Art Today, Soul Catchers, and The Latin American Spirit: Art and Artists’ Presence in the US, 1920-1970 can be found in this series.
Many of these files have been kept in their original order with original folder headings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous exhibition invites and brochures from some of the galleries Carla Stellweg was associated with including: Carla Stellweg Gallery, Stellweg-Seguy Gallery, Blue Star Art Space and White Box, among others. The artists represented in the brochures include: Jesse Amado, Blade, Lola Alvarez Bravo, Luis Camnitzer, Carlos Capelan, Monica Castillo, Arturo Elizondo, Carlos Garaicoa, Maria Elena Gonzalez, David Lamelas, Luz Maria Gordillo, David Mach, David Moreno, Jaime Palacios, Tatiana Parcero, Liliana Porter, Juan Sanchez, Eugenia Vargas, Kukuli Velarde and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series documents the gallery exhibit The Camera Seduced: Portraits of Frida Kahlo, which led to publication of a book of the same name. Starting as a gallery exhibit, the show traveled to 12 venues worldwide. In addition to information about the exhibition, the series contains research for the show, including newspaper clippings.

Series 4. Articles, Reviews, and Other Writing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains files on Stellweg's articles, reviews and other written works. Materials include correspondence, typescripts, and publications containing articles by Stellweg. Such publications include Vie Des Arts, Vanguard, Art Nexus, ARTnews, as well as various artist books and catalogs. Information on The Camera Seduced: Portraits of Frida Kahlo can be found in Series 3. Frida Kahlo Exhibits. Some of Stellweg’s articles may also be found in Series 5. Publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Series 5 contains two subseries. The first subseries, Related to Exhibits and Artists, contains art magazines and exhibition catalogs, including the autographed catalogs of several artists. Many of these publications are marked with notes, often indicating an article that relates to Stellweg or an artist involved with her gallery. Publications and art catalogs from Blue Star Art Space and White Box can be found in this subseries. A full run of Artes Visuales, a magazine which Stellweg founded and edited, is included. Other publications include Excelsior, Atlantica, Vie des Arts, and Art Nexus.
The second subseries, Consultation and Research, is comprised of publications which were used as research for Stellweg’s consultation work, writing, and other professional activities.
This series is arranged alphabetically within the two subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The accession consists of materials that were received at a later date than the rest of the collection. It contains materials that are related to other materials in the collection.

The accession documents Stellweg's professional activities as a curator, and director of various art galleries and museums, including her work at the Carla Stellweg Gallery, the Stellweg-Seguy Gallery, the Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art (MOCHA), the Rufino Tamayo Museum, Blue Star Art Space, and White Box. The accession also documents her professional activities as a consultant and speaker for publications, seminars, symposiums, exhibitions and gallery shows. Additionally the accession contains information on artists, many of whom Carla Stellweg represented and whose artwork she sold.

Materials include correspondence, documentation on artists and exhibitions, catalogs, art auction catalogs, exhibition invitations, appointment books, administrative records, pricelists, invoices, loan agreements, drafts of presentations, and research material for Stellweg’s consultation and curatorial work.

Among other formats, this accession contains photographs, slides, negatives, microcassettes, VHS tapes, CDs, DVDs, and a hard-drive. The images include exhibitions and artwork as well as personal photographs. Many of the images are individually labeled.
Many of the files have been kept in their original order with original folder headings and original descriptive notes.

Chuck Ramirez - Blue Star Contemporary Art Center Board member and artist

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chuck Ramirez was a board member at Blue Star Contemporary Art Center and a successful artist. He was the prime advocate to have Carla Stellweg become Blue Star’s first professional executive director & chief curator – prior to then Blue Star had been an artist-run alternative space founded in July of 1985. The anniversary of its founding became a Citywide celebration titled “San Antonio Contemporary Art Month”. Related to materials in Box 26.

did.unittitle: Catalog, Basado en una Historia/Based on a True Story, for a group exhibition of the same name curated by Yael Rosenblut at the Museo de Salvador Allende, Chile

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The exhibition featured sophisticated video artists whose works incorporated elements of film in order to challenge conventional narrative structures while at the same time expanding the creative limits of the moving image. The catalog was edited by Alan Meller with Carla Stellweg text, Patrick Jolley: una Vida Idiosincrática y Peripatética appearing on pp. 9-12. Published in Chile: Museo de la Solidaridad Salvador Allende, 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, insurance info, notes and a 4 x 5 negative regarding the work of artist Jorge Salazar (later sold at Rago Contemporary Art auction in the fall of 2014). Salazar was an artist Carla Stellweg promoted and got a solo exhibition at P.S. 1 (today PS1-MoMA) which in turn landed him a solo show with Germans van Eck Gallery, 420 West Broadway which led later to his exclusive representation with Gallery Ramis Barquet, Fuller Building, East 57th Street and Monterrey, Mexico.

Alan Robbins and Juan Castro y Velázquez – both of which purchased Gutierrez’s work from Carla Stellweg Gallery – as well as with registrar Silvia Vega from the Museo de Monterrey, Mexico. Folder also contains shipping receipts, pricelists and exhibition invites.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Kate Augenblick pricelist, letters, exhibition invite and correspondence with doctor and collector Thomas S. Schultz regarding her work.

did.unittitle: Various Carla Stellweg Gallery documents regarding art sales

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes invoices, related information, slides and photographs. Sold artists include Eugenia Vargas, Jeff Koons, Keith Haring, Diego Rivera, Rufino Tamayo, Elijah Pierce, Roberto Matta, Jose Luis Cuevas, Neal Slavin, Leonora Carrington, Alfredo Castañeda, Andres Serrano, Komar and Melamid, Ray Smith, Hector Garcia, Cildo Meireles, Ana Mendieta, Lola Alvarez Bravo and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, consignment notes and exhibition pamphlets. The Fogarty pieces are some of the approximately 140 pieces of works from her photography collection that became part of a donation and purchase to Lehigh University Art Galleries in the fall of 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included are pricelists, consignment forms, photographs and correspondence regarding the work of artist Ray Smith, from Sperone-Westwater; Krasdale Foods; Y-Gallery NY and OMR Gallery, Mexico. Most of these works were sold at Rago Contemporary Art sale in November 2014

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, faxes, shipping information and invites. Quintana’s pieces from Carla Stellweg’s collection were purchased-sold by Cuban Modern Art scholar and private dealer, Rafael Diaz-Casas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondences, faxes and articles about Humberto Castro's work. Pieces of Castro's work from Carla Stellweg’s collection were also purchased-sold by Cuban Modern Art scholar and private dealer, Rafael Diaz-Casas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten letters from Carlos Zerpa - whose early work as a performance artist Carla Stellweg published during the 1970s in Artes Visuales and later Carla Stellweg Gallery handled his work during the 1990s when the artist resided and worked in New York City, all of which were subsequently auctioned at Rago Contemporary Art Sale, November, 2014 (except for a collage work still in Carla Stellweg Collection).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters to and from Ana-Albertina Delgado as well as a Carla Stellweg Gallery invitational letter to Adriano Buergo to speak about “To Create Art In and Outside Cuba Today,” (Jan. 11, 1993). They were purchased-sold by Cuban Modern Art scholar and private dealer, Rafael Diaz-Casas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consignment letters and information from the OMR Gallery, Mexico, D.F., for two pieces by Monica Castillo, loaned to Carla Stellweg Gallery and subsequently passed on to Grace Borgenicht Gallery and exhibited in a group show of 1990s Neo-Mexican artists. One of these was sold to a Chicago doctor, collector friend of Francine Birbragher (daughter of Celia Sredni de Birbragher founder and owner of ArtNexus).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consignment letter, faxes and shipping receipt from the OMR Gallery, Mexico, D.F., for triptych by artist Nestor Quiñones, purchased by Carla Stellweg Gallery and sold at Rago Contemporary Art auction in November, 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes to Carla Stellweg by Puerto Rican photographer Victor Vazquez. Eight of his photographs that were in Carla Stellweg’s photography collection became part of the donation and purchase to Lehigh University Art Galleries in the fall of 2014. Several other large pieces left with Carla Stellweg Gallery were destroyed in Hurricane Sandy storage flooding.

did.unittitle: Letter from the secretary of Raymond Page inquiring about Cuban artist Maria Elena Gonzalez

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondences and consignment forms between Carla Stellweg and photographer Marta-Maria Perez Bravo for a group exhibition of women photographs at Carla Stellweg Gallery in 1996. Photographs were sold to a Native-American artist from Arizona, Frank Lapena (1994); and at Miami Art Fair to Egon von Fürstenberg (1995); privately to Pamela Rosenau (1996); and Jerry Suarez (2009).

did.unittitle: Patricia Martín Briceño and Alberto Tovalin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carla Stellweg Gallery correspondences with artists Patricia Martín Briceño and Alberto Tovalin. Carla Stellweg owned originally 5-6 Black-and-White photographs, several were included in Lola Alvarez Bravo Plus Modern and Contemporary Mexican Artists, May 3- June 1, 1991; and one was included in the 1990s San Antonio Museum of Art exhibition of Women Photographing Women (with Graciela Iturbide, Sandra Eleta, Lola Alvarez-Bravo etc.). Two were sold to Sandra Cisneros; and two more to a private collector in Austin, Texas. One remains in the Carla Stellweg Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mónica Girón correspondences and price list. Carla Stellweg purchased three works that were offered at auction and remain unsold at this time, at Rago Contemporary Art sale in November, 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter and loan agreement between New Museum and Carla Stellweg Gallery for four pieces by Kukuli Velarde to be included in the exhibition, Labor of Love (Jan. 20 – April 14, 1996), curated by Marcia Tucker for the New Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Carla Stellweg Gallery and Esterio Segura along with consignment form. Carla Stellweg owns a piece by Segura with sculpture dated 1994 and purchased during the Habana Biennial. See Carla Stellweg Art Inventory on External.

did.unittitle: Letter to the De Menil Collection promoting Carla Stellweg Gallery artists

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter to the De Menil Collection of Houston, Texas, promoting Carla Stellweg Gallery artists Carlos Capelan, Juan Sanchez, Luis Camnitzer, Maria Elena Gonzalez and Jaime Palacios.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cuban artist Segundo Planes’s invite for Paternidad: Paintings by Segundo Planes at the Mackey Gallery, Houston, Texas. Planes was part of the Carla Stellweg’s Collection purchased by Cuban Modern Art scholar and private dealer Rafael Diaz-Casas who in turn sold them to his clients. Folder also includes a pricelist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 2011 Various art loans and related materials from the collection of Carla Stellweg, including: Aperture Foundation’s exhibition, Lola Alvarez Bravo (September 8-November 2, 2006), a landmark exhibition of work by Mexico’s first great woman photographer, curated by Elizabeth Ferrer; Mary-Anne Martin Fine Art’s consignment of Alfredo Castañeda (sold in 2014 at Morton Subastas, Mexico City; Throckmorton Fine Art’s consignment of Salvador Lutteroth and payment; plus loan and insurance agreements and return of works from the Bronx Museum’s show, Arte no es Vida: Actions by Artists of the Americas, 1960-2000 that included four Eugenia Vargas pieces.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Important catalogs, invites and exhibition related materials including: the catalog for the 11th Havana Biennial in 2012, Detrás del Muro (Behind the Wall); an invite/program for ArtTable’s 20th Annual Award Ceremony and Benefit Luncheon, honoring Patricia Phelps de Cisneros; checklist for an exhibition at Gallery 151 entitled, A False Horizon: Art from Latin America, curated by PEANA Projects (Aug. 3 – Sept. 3, 2015); an invite to the Smithsonian National Portrait Gallery for the exhibition, Portraiture Now: Staging the Self (Aug. 22 – April 12, 2015; an exhibition brochure for Philippe Parreno’s show H {N)Y P N(Y} OSIS at the Park Avenue Armory (June 11 – Aug. 2, 2015); etc.

did.unittitle: Invites, correspondence, pricelist and preparatory/research materials for the exhibition, Intimate Portraits of the Immortal Frida Kahlo, at Lincart Gallery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The exhibition used photographs from Carla Stellweg’s Frida Kahlo portraits collection at Lincart Gallery in San Francisco. Included in this folder are scans of letters from Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera (1940), written while Frida was in St. Luke’s Hospital, San Francisco, requesting money from an Alberto and Anita Misrachi, the Misrachi Gallery in Mexico City Central de Publicaciones.

Miscellaneous CDs, DVDs and floppy disks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are 23 CD-Rs and DVD-Rs. There are 66 3.5" floppy disks. Some of the CD-Rs and DVD-Rs are related to exhibitions and shows that are also documented in other locations in the collection. Some of the materials have a brief description from Carla Stellweg explaining the relation to other materials and the context.
